slides.originalNotes:
The intake process: automated claim setup
When a claim is created in the New Claim Wizard, is entered through the portal or is imported from an external FNOL application, it enters the automated claim setup process.

Three primary things occur during claim setup.

First, the claim is segmented. Segmentation is the process of determining the strategy for how the claim should be processed.  (For example, is the claim straight-forward or is it complex enough to require adjusters with special expertise?)

Then, the claim is assigned. Assignment is the act of determining who is responsible for the claim. The user creating the claim can specify who itshould be assigned to, or the assignment could be determined using automated rules.

Finally, a series of activities known as the "workplan" are created and assigned. These activities identify the work that must be done to process the claim and who must do it.

Claim setup is run only when the NCW completes, or when you call the addFNOL() method from the web services API, or when using the "Edge" API for the
Guidewire Claim Portal. You cannot invoke setup from rules.

Loaded rules
Claim Loaded rules execute when a new claim is loaded through the FNOL import interface. ClaimCenter executes Loaded rules when it finishes importing or loading" a claim from an external FNOL source. The purpose of this rule category is to make any changes necessary to convert initial claim data from an external format int  a suitable structure for ClaimCenter- In addition, you can create Loaded rules to record the import of claims.

You can create whatever rules are appropriate to handle the import of new claims:

Sanity checks

Data aggregations and transformations

Data and naming reconciliations

Claim import logging

Obviously this involves integration with the external FNOL application, and the specifics of the "Loaded" rule sets are completely dependent upon the specifics of what the extemal application provides  ClaimCenter- Because of this, the ClaimLoaded and ExposureLoaded rule sets provided in the base configuration of ClaimCenter are just stubs that do not actually do anything and must be configured for your FNOL application(s), if any.

Presetup rules
Sometimes, there are actions that must take place before a claim can be segmented, regardless of how it enters ClaimCenter. The Presetup rule sets exist to perform those actions.

The most common presetup action is the creation of one or more exposures based on the nature of the claim. In the base configuration, the only setup rule that exists creates the relevant exposures for a Workers’ Compensation claim — which may include a Medical Details exposure, an Indemnity exposure (called a Time Loss exposure prior to ClaimCenter 9), and/or a Liability exposure.

Note that this functionality is also available in the business rules, on the ClaimCenter administrative pages.

Segmentation rules apply only to claims and exposures, and only during claim setup. The purpose of segmentation is to determine the strategy for working with the claim or exposure. This simplifies logic in later rule sets, such as: 
Assignment routing
Activity creation

In the base configuration, this is based on the complexity of the individual exposure.  exposure is segmented as to low,  medium, or high complexity.  Only after all the exposures are segmented is the claim segmented, which is different from all the other setup rule sets. This is because the most common strategy for segmenting a claim is to assign it to  segment of the most complex exposure.

slides.originalNotes:
Assignment rules
Assignment is the process of determining what group and individual will have responsibility for a given object, in this case a claim or exposure. Typically, all exposures will be assigned to the same group and individual as the claim, but you can write rules to do it differently.

Assignment rules are run when a claim (or exposure) is created and the "use automatic assignment" option is chosen. The claim is assigned first, and then its exposures. The exposure owner is not necessarily the same as the claim owner. However, unless it meets a special circumstance, each exposure is typically assigned to the same group and user as the claim.

Assignment rules are also run  outside of setup when a claim or exposure is reassigned and the reassigning user selects the "use automatic assignment" option.

Assignment may rely on the claim's segment, but can also use other characteristics of the claim, such as geography, the strategic importance of a customer, and so on.

Assignment is covered in detail in another lesson in this course.

slides.originalNotes:
Segmentation versus assignment
Sometimes the distinction between segmentation and assignment is not intuitively clear The thing to remember is that segmentation determines the strategy for the claim or exposure, while assignment determines who is responsible for processing the claim, exposure, or other object, and may or may not be based on segment.

Also, while segmentation is done only during the setup of claims and exposures, assignment may take place multiple times during the life cycle of a given object — for example, a claim which has been automatically assigned may be reassigned to a different worker. This may be done manually, or it may be done automatically, in which case, the relevant assignment rule set runs again.

slides.originalNotes:
Workplan rules
ClaimCenter tracks the work required on a given claim orexposure using activities. An activity is a description of work that needs to be done, which is assigned to some group and individual. The Workplan for a claim is all the activities created, manually or by rules, for the claim or any of its exposures. Workplan rules are used to create initial activities for a claim (first) and then the exposure. For example:
Investigate accident scene (claim level)
Get police report (claim level)
Contact claimant (exposure level)
Get damage estimates for vehicle (exposure level)
Each new activity is run through its own Presetup, Assignment and Postsetup rule set.
Activities can also be created for a claim after it has completed setup. These activities also go through the activity rule sets.

Preupdate and validation rules
Preupdate and Validation rules run not only when an object is created, but also when it is changed — in effect, any time an attempt is made to save the
object to the database.

The purpose of preupdate rules is to perform final actions to the claim or exposure.

The purpose of validation rules is to make sure that the object is complete, correct, and consistent. They allow ClaimCenter to reject an object if it does not meet standards of completeness, correctness, and consistency.

reject ( ) functions are never called in Preupdate rules.

Changes or additions are never made in validation rules.

Validation rules are covered in detail in another lesson in this course.

Segment fields
Both the Claim and Exposure entities have a typekey field named Segment, which refer  to the ClaimSegment typelist. So, if you want to create rules that use segments not found in the base application, you must first modify the ClaimSegment typelist.

Recall that Studio caches typelist values during start-up. So, if you create new segments and need Studio to be aware of them, you must stop and restart Studio after the typelist is extended.

slides.originalNotes:
Exit after segmenting
Once you have set the value of the object's Segment, there is no reason to continue in the rule set. Furthermore, there is some risk that a sibling rule further down in the list will reset your segmentation value in a way that you do not want. Therefore, it is important to execute the actions.exit() method in the rule ACTION as soon as the object has an appropriate segment. This method exits the entire rule set. In the example above, if the rule CONDITION returns true, the Segment value of "auto_high" is set and the rule set is exited. If the rule CONDITION returns false, the next rule in the Exposure Segmentation rule set executes (ESGOI 400 – Auto Default). This rule applies to any exposure with a Segment value of "null". In the base application,this rule sets the value ofSegment to •auto_mid", and exits from the rule set.

As stated earlier, the sequential execution of rules proceeds vertically from top to bottom until a rule CONDITION returns true and an actions.exit() statement at the end of the rule ACTION terminates execution. Thus, it is important to order rules in a logical sequence, with the most important or urgent rules coming first.

slides.originalNotes:
Claim segmentation rules in the base application (2 of 2)
In the base configuration of ClaimCenter, a simple logic, consisting of one parent and b,vo child rules, is used to segment claims. The example shown is specific to auto claims, but similar logic applies to all loss types.

The parent rule tests for the Loss Cause.

The first child rule checks to see if any exposures have been created for the claim. If there are exposures, it then selects thehighest (most complex) segment of the exposures and assigns the claim to that segment.

The second rule only runs if the first rule does not find any exposures. It assigns the claim to a default segment, in this case •auto low".
